Notes: Probably far too tricky because of legal arguments concerning the type of present and precedents.

Statement: One of the Koch brothers' anti-Obamacare groups is going to college campuses, giving away free booze to try to bribe young folks out of getting health insurance
They (The Koch brothers)'re the richest people in the world. Individually they're only fifth. Put them together they're the richest in the world.
The death tax makes it harder for us to hand our farm on to our kids
Notes: Subjective

Statement: It was only in the past decade that I realized the need to also engage in the political process.
Notes: Fluid categories, not clear how to judge political engagement

Statement: The purpose of Obamacare was not to get 7 million people or 6 million people, or whatever the number now is, to sign up on a website. The purpose of Obamacare, according to them, was to get more people  insurance. And by all accounts, it's going to fall woefully short.  You're still going to have 30-some-odd million people in this country  uninsured.
Notes: The way he phrased it, he doesn't actually commit to a number ...

Statement: EPA officials have commended us (Koch industries) for our ‘commitment to a cleaner environment’ and called us ‘a model for other companies.
Notes: Quote is true, but in reference to a specific process and not in reference to a company. It is a statement about a statement though, so we avoided it.

Statement: This is the first time since WWII that five nuclear-powered aircraft carriers were docked together
Michelle Obama waves red communist flags on her taxpayer-funded visit to China
Notes: Tricky resolution, though, as this requires image analysis to establish that the flag she is waving is not the Chinese national flag

Statement: When people enlist in the military, there is a physical check but there's not a mental health evaluation when people enter the service
More than 3 million young adults ... have gained insurance under (the Affordable Care Act) by staying on their family’s plan.
Notes: Various estimates in circulation, no precise up-to-date numbers

Statement: Who will raising the minimum wage actually help? More than half work full-time. The average worker is 35 years old.
Now they [The Koch brothers] are spending millions to buy a Senate seat for Bill Cassidy so he can fight for them
Notes: Rather subjective

Statement: Before Congress, Cotton got paid handsomely working for insurance companies and corporate interests.
Notes: Worked for McKinsey, which is not an insurance company. Consulted insurance companies, thus worked indirectly for them

Statement: Fuel poverty went up under Labour.
Notes: Numerically verifiable

Statement: Under this Government, we’ve maintained the winter fuel payments
Notes: Numerically verifiable

Statement: We have increased the cold weather payments.
Notes: Numerically verifiable

Statement: The government has updated the benefit to cost ratio (BCR) of the railway, valuing it at 2.3, or providing £2 worth of benefits for every £1 spent. This is similar to Crossrail and higher than the benefit cost ratio for some other major projects when approved, such as Thameslink and the Jubilee Line extension.
Notes: Not explicitely mentioned who made the statement

Statement: Lord Nash has given false information to parliament and he should correct the error at the earliest opportunity.
Notes: Accusation, personal opinion

Owner: Dr Hilary Emery, Chief Executive of the National Children’s Bureau
Statement: Data shows five excess child deaths per day in UK compared to Sweden
Notes: Numerically verifiable. Interestingly the verdict is not just about the number, but also on whether this particular comparison is informative.

Owner: Anne Marie Waters, council member of the National Secular Society
Statement: The number of women wearing the burka and niqab has exploded in Britain in recent decades
Notes: Numerically verifiable, Exact date is not known (August 2013)

Statement: There’s overwhelming support for banning the veil. People feel it’s alien to our way of life.
Notes: Public opinion, possible to verify

Owner: Dr Sarah Wollaston MP for Totnes
Statement: The niqab … collude[s] with making women invisible.
Notes: (Personal?) opinion, hard to verify

Statement: The police put millions of innocent people under surveillance in order to catch a tiny minority of wrongdoers. Perhaps now it is time to make officers wear a camera and microphone while on duty. When they tried this in California, use of force by police officers dropped by two-thirds in a year.
Notes: Could be seen as speculation, but one part of the analogy can be verified. The verdict is also about whether they trust the numbers.

Statement: Foreign visitors owe the NHS £2bn
Notes: Numerically verifiable

Statement: If people at home want to be able to keep watching the television, be able to turn the kettle on, and benefit from electricity, we have got to make these investments. It is essential to keep the lights on.
Notes: Which investments (nuclear reactor) is not clear from wording, also the causality is hard to assess

Owner: Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt, National Children’s and Adults Services conference
Statement: [I am] struck by the reverence and respect for older people in Asian culture. In those countries, when living alone is no longer possible, residential care is a last, rather than a first option

Owner: Mark Rimmer, a senior Registrar in Brent and head of the Local Registration Services Association
Statement: In an area like London it would not be unreasonable to say that 20% of all our marriages are suspicious.
Notes: Numerically verifiable. One would probably need context to tell that this about visas

Statement: Who, according to JK Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter novels, was Harry Potter’s first girlfriend? Who is the first person he kisses? That’s right, Cho Chang – who is a Chinese overseas student at Hogwarts school.
Notes: Not sure if Cho is Chinese (name doesn't sound so)

Statement: One hundred and sixty million Chinese are watching Downton Abbey, which is more than double the number of people who live in the UK.
Notes: It is mentioned as a fact which turns out to be a speculation.

Statement: Take your great high-tech company, Huawei. There are some western governments that have blocked Huawei from making investments. Not Britain. Quite the opposite.
More than 50 per cent of women who enter jail have been physically, sexually, or emotionally abused. And those are statistics quoted by everybody.
Notes: Numerically verifiable. The verdict assumes that statement is made for abuse in adult years, not sure though this is correct to assume though.

Statement: The Immigration Bill will [..] reduce the pull factors which encourage people to come to the UK and make it easier to remove people who should not be here.
Notes: Speculation

Statement: A SUN investigation today reveals disturbing failings in Britain’s mental health system that have allowed high-risk patients to kill 1,200 people in a decade.
Notes: Numerically verifiable

Statement: New Lotto gives you more ways to win more money.
Notes: Math needed
